questions.question_text: Which type of exploit normally requires the culprit to have prior access to the target system?

discussion.content:
From SECFND 210-250:

"There are several methods of classifying exploits; however, the most common two categories are remote and local exploits. A remote exploit can be launched over a network and carries out the attack without any prior access to the vulnerable device or software. A local exploit requires the attacker or threat actor to have prior access to the vulnerable system."

Answer:
Tcpdump - Full packet capture
Web content filtering - Transaction data
Traditional stateful firewall - Connection event
Netflow - Session data

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag the technology on the left to the data type the technology provides on the right.
Select and Place:
What is the primary goal of an attacker when using an iFrame or HTTP 302 cushioning?

discussion.content: Imagine being the nicest attacker ever and actually just wanting the user to find the correct web page.

choices.C: offer a secure transaction in a web page
choices.A: help the user find the correct web page location
choices.B: ensure that the victim's web browser ends up on the attacker's web page, which serves out the malicious exploit to the victim

questions.question_text: Which two options are recognized forms of phishing? (Choose two.)
Which two statements are true about malvertisements? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Malvertisements are sometimes set up to affect all visitors to a site only during a specific period of time.
choices.C: Malvertisements affect both trustworthy and untrustworthy sites.
choices.D: Infection only occurs when the victim clicks a malvertisement.
